description: The VitalFit Coach retrieves the user’s recent fitness tracker data and then creates a personalized, progressive calisthenics (bodyweight) workout program tailored to the user’s goals and current activity levels.

messages.content: You are VitalFit Coach, an agentic LLM that acts as a personal health coach. Use the provided tools to fetch fitness data, generate workout plans, and respond to the user with clear, actionable recommendations.
Hi! I’m only interested in bodyweight training. I want a progressive calisthenics program that helps me build strength and lose a few pounds. Can you put something together for me?

Absolutely! To design the best program I’ll first pull your recent fitness‑tracker metrics so I can tailor the intensity and volume to your current activity level.

Fetching data now...

Thanks for the data! I see you average about 8,000 steps per day, 72 bpm resting heart rate, 8 hours of sleep nightly, and roughly 350 active minutes per week. Based on your goal of strength‑building and weight loss, I’ll generate a 4‑week progressive calisthenics plan that increases difficulty each week while keeping volume manageable.

Generating the workout plan now…

Week 1 (Foundation – 3 sessions)
• Day 1: Push‑ups 3×8, Bodyweight Squats 3×12, Plank 3×30s, Walking Lunges 2×10 each leg
• Day 2: Pull‑ups (assisted) 3×5, Dips (bench) 3×8, Glute Bridge 3×15, Side Plank 2×20s each side
• Day 3: Incline Push‑ups 3×10, Jump Squats 3×8, Hollow Hold 3×20s, Mountain Climbers 3×30s
Rest 48 h between sessions.

Week 2 (Progress – 4 sessions)
• Add a fourth session on Day 4.
• Increase reps by ~20% and introduce negatives for pull‑ups.
• Example Day 1: Push‑ups 4×10, Squats 4×15, Plank 4×40s, Walking Lunges 3×12.
• Day 2: Assisted Pull‑ups 4×6 (2‑second negative), Bench Dips 4×10, Glute Bridge 4×20, Side Plank 3×30s.
• Day 3: Incline Push‑ups 4×12, Jump Squats 4×10, Hollow Hold 4×30s, Mountain Climbers 4×45s.
• Day 4 (Active Recovery): Light cardio 20 min, Mobility flow 15 min.

Week 3 (Load – 4 sessions, higher intensity)
• Introduce tempo work: 3‑second eccentric on push‑ups and squats.
• Add Bulgarian Split‑Squats 3×8 each leg.
• Example Day 1: Push‑ups 4×8 (3‑sec ecc), Squats 4×12 (3‑sec ecc), Plank 4×45s, Bulgarian Split‑Squats 3×8.
• Day 2: Pull‑ups 4×5 (assisted if needed, 3‑sec ecc), Dips 4×8, Glute Bridge 4×25, Side Plank 3×40s.
• Day 3: Decline Push‑ups 4×6, Jump Squats 4×12, Hollow Hold 4×35s, Mountain Climbers 4×60s.
• Day 4: HIIT 20 min (30s work/30s rest) + Stretching 10 min.

Week 4 (Peak – 5 sessions, volume taper)
• Reduce total volume slightly but increase difficulty (e.g., full‑body push‑ups, pistol‑squat progressions).
• Day 1: Archer Push‑ups 3×6, Pistol‑Squat assisted 3×5 each leg, Plank 3×60s.
• Day 2: Weighted Pull‑ups (if possible) 3×4, Bench Dips 3×12, Glute Bridge 3×30.
• Day 3: Hand‑Release Push‑ups 3×10, Jump Squats 3×15, Hollow Hold 3×45s.
• Day 4: Light cardio 30 min + Mobility 15 min.
• Day 5: Full‑body circuit (2 rounds): Push‑ups 12, Squats 15, Pull‑ups 5, Dips 10, Plank 60s.

All weeks include a warm‑up (5‑10 min dynamic stretching) and a cool‑down (5 min static stretching). Aim for progressive overload: increase reps, add a slower tempo, or use a resistance band as you get stronger.

Nutrition tip: maintain a modest calorie deficit (~300 kcal below maintenance) with ~1.6 g protein per kg body weight to support muscle gain while losing fat.

Here’s your 4‑week progressive calisthenics program, fully customized to your recent activity levels and goals. The plan starts with a solid foundation in Week 1 and builds intensity each week, culminating in a peak week with advanced bodyweight movements. Follow the warm‑up and cool‑down suggestions, keep your nutrition around a slight calorie deficit with adequate protein, and you should see improvements in strength and body composition.

If you have any questions about a specific exercise, need modifications, or want a complementary meal plan, just let me know!
